text: well actually surveys I have seen
indicate about 40% of scientists uh
believe in a God to whom one may pray in
expectation of an
answer that's not a God uh who went off
after con creating the universe and did
something else that's a god who's
interested in human beings
40% uh would adhere to that statement
the numbers are smaller when you ask
members of the National Academy of
Sciences and there's various reasons
people have proposed why so-called Elite
scientists have an even lower proportion
of Believers uh but it's not as
devastatingly absent from the scientific
Community as people might assume based
on the fact that the pronouncements they
hear coming from scientists are usually
more in the skeptical or even atheistic
uh
perspective I think whether or not uh
scientists are believers uh should not
have a whole lot to do with they conduct
science the fact that I am a believer as
far as I'm aware of has had very little
influence on my scientific work and I
think that's important to keep that
distinction if I'm asking a scientific
question it's the tools of science I
should be using and not assuming that
something Supernatural happened in the
test tube at that moment and that would
explain my data point uh so I do think
people of faith and people who don't
have faith are capable of thoughtful
ethical decision making so any notion
that we are becoming less ethical as
scientists because of a diminution in
religious faith I think has to be
actually countered uh by uh arguments to
say that a sense of ethical behavior is
not uh distributed uh to just to people
who are in fact interested in spiritual
matters um so I'm not sure I think it
would diminish the hostilities which are
bad for our culture if more scientists
were uh in fact willing to stand up and
say that faith and science need not to
be in conflict because right now that's
a minority view that doesn't get heard
very much and it's apparent to some
people that we're having more of a
cultural War a war that seems to imply
that some worldview needs to win and
some worldview needs to
lose I would not want to look forward to
a culture where science lost and
religious faith became the dominating
Force for truth I would not want to live
in a culture uh where Faith lost and
science with all of its reductionism and
its materialism became the sole source
of truth I think we need both kinds of
Truth we need both kinds of worldviews
to the extent that scientists can help
with that realization of the Dual uh
ways of finding answers to the
appropriate kind of questions that each
worldview can ask then I think that
would be a good
thing certainly the social biology ol
ologists have put forward arguments that
religion could have an evolutionary
basis that we humans are designed in a
certain way to look for agency behind
actions that we don't understand and
that may then relate uh to why various
cultures over time uh have identified
something uh mysterious and Supernatural
outside of their own experience to try
to explain things that didn't otherwise
have an explanation I think it's too
simple uh to basically say well that
does it either God is true or God is not
true either God is real or God is not
real it's not a matter of whether you
can explain it away by a hypothesis the
question is what's the real answer and I
think far too few people have kind of
looked at the question from that
perspective what's the evidence uh for
the idea that God exists or doesn't
exist I think anyone who's looked at
that would conclude that the strong
atheist pos position of saying I know
there is no God uh is not an easy one to
sustain uh it it it basically implies a
certain degree of hubris and arrogance
to say that I know so much that I could
exclude any possibility of there being a
God on the other hand the evidence will
never draw people to the conclusion of
saying I know confidently there is a God
maybe God didn't intend it to be that
easy
